Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Wet Printing of Carbon Nanotube-Enhanced Osmosis Membranes for Water Desalination

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1510207
Zhang
Cal Poly St Univ

The proposed research uses nanotechnology to redesign osmosis membranes for cost-effective desalination and purification of water. In particular, a solution-based printing technique is proposed to fabricate large-area, vertically-aligned carbon nanotube-based osmosis membranes. A systematic analysis of the structure-processing-property correlations will provide a foundation for the optimization of new multifunctional nanomaterials. The transformative research driven by this concept will have the potential to radically change current scientific understanding on new water treatment technologies to meet water resource needs in energy-constrained areas. The educational impacts of this proposal include the development of new undergraduate curricula to strengthen students? desire for lifelong learning. A large number of undergraduate students, including under-represented students and women, will receive the multidisciplinary training on chemistry, physics, materials and engineering. The outreach activities will target local K-12 students and teachers.

The research in this project is aimed to develop facile screen-printing systems for massive production of nano-enhanced, ordered osmosis membranes from liquid crystalline solutions. The target osmosis membranes consist of vertically aligned carbon nanotubes in the polymer matrix. Carbon nanotubes will be dispersed in liquid crystals of polymerizable surfactants that serve as an orientation template to organize nanotubes in the surfactant micellar cores. The ink printability in relation to the rheology of nanotube dispersions will be evaluated systematically. During screen-printing, the vertical shear flow will allow surfactant wrapped nanotubes to reorient themselves to form vertically aligned nanostructures on the substrate, which will be subsequently photo-polymerized into aligned nanotube-polymer composites. Finally, the porous polyamide will be incorporated into aligned nanotube composites to produce nano-enhanced, ordered osmosis membranes. Such ordered nanostructures will maximize fast water flux and minimize biofouling in molecular channels of vertically aligned carbon nanotubes.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project has used nanotechnology to re-design the osmosis membranes for water desalination with reduced energy consumption and enhanced filtration performance. In particular, nanocarbon-based membranes such as single-walled carbon nanotubes have demonstrated great promise owing to frictionless and ultrafast water transport inside the nanotubes. In general, the nanotubes are physically mixed with the polymer to produce the mixed matrix membrane; however, the resulting disordered structures degrade the membrane performance. The objective of this project is to fabricate the ordered mixed matrix membranes using facile printing techniques. In doing so, a liquid crystal templating method is applied to incorporate single-walled carbon nanotubes into the polymer matrix and a wet-printing process is used to fabricate the ordered mixed matrix membranes. 

This research project combines the molecular design and chemical synthesis to produce a series of polymerizable surfactants that are able to disperse and exfoliate single-walled carbon nanotubes in the lyotropic liquid crystalline mesophases. Liquid crystal phase diagram is established as a function of concentration, hydrocarbon length of surfactant, temperature and nanotubes. Incorporation of nanotubes does not alter liquid crystal mesophases but enhances the structural ordering. Shear-thinning effect is received in the nanotube-liquid crystal mixture. After photo-polymerization, the liquid crystal structures are altered. A physical model has been developed to address polymerization-induced structure alternation. Both screen-printing and draw-down methods are applied to fabricate aligned membranes on the porous support of polyethersulfone. The out-of-plane alignment is found under the appropriate printing conditions and confirmed by small-angle X-ray scattering. The nanofiltration performance of the designed membranes is evaluated using the dead-end nanofiltration system in terms of water permeation, ion rejection and molecular separation. Incorporation of nanotubes into the membrane has enhanced nanofiltration performance.

This research project has provided opportunities to establish cross departmental collaborations among four faculty on campus. During the award period, one faculty has been tenured and promoted to Associate Professor and two other faculty have been promoted to Full Professor. The research project has also provided financial support and mentorship of 20 undergraduate research students including two Master graduate students via the 4 + 1 program and three community college students. The project has provided research opportunities for two undergraduate students to conduct summer research in the R1 institutions and one Master graduate student to conduct thesis research in the R1 institution. As a result, national and international research collaborations between PUI and R1 have been established through this research project. In addition, the project has provided opportunities for undergraduate research students to attend regional and national meetings to deliver oral presentations and posters. The PI has incorporated the research data from this project into the graduate course curriculum and promoted independent research projects on desalination in the laboratory course.

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2020
Modified by: Shanju Zhang
